    Robust Median-Distance Heuristic for RBF Bandwidth

    sigma_med.Rd

    sigma_med concatenates X and Y, optionally subsamples rows, computes all pairwise Euclidean distances, and returns their median as a robust bandwidth heuristic.

    sigma_med(X, Y, m = 400, seed = NULL)

    Arguments

    X

    Numeric matrix (n_1 × p).

    Y

    Numeric matrix (n_2 × p) with the same number of columns as X.

    m

    Integer: maximum number of rows used. If total rows exceed m, a uniform without-replacement subsample is taken. Default 400.

    seed

    Optional integer seed for reproducibility.

    Value

    Positive scalar median Euclidean distance; NA_real_ if insufficient data.

    Details

    If the combined sample size is \(\le 2\), returns NA_real_ with a warning. If the median distance is zero (e.g., many duplicates), returns a machine-epsilon positive constant.

    See also

    Other kernels-metrics: compute_distance_matrix(), compute_energy(), compute_mmd(), compute_wasserstein(), rbf_kernel()

    Examples

    if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
set.seed(42)
X <- matrix(rnorm(100), 20, 5); Y <- matrix(rnorm(100, 1), 20, 5)
# Use all rows (N <= m)
sigma_all <- sigma_med(X, Y)

# Subsample at most 15 rows
sigma_sub <- sigma_med(X, Y, m = 15, seed = 1)
} # }
